causes: Resistance of the indigenous Mapuche to European colonization
Spanish attempts to establish control over southern Chile
events_leading_up_to_war: Diego de Almagro's expedition (1535–1536) first encountered Mapuche resistance.
Pedro de Valdivia attempted to conquer Araucanía and establish Spanish settlements in 1541.
Battle of Tucapel (1553) saw the Mapuche capture and kill Pedro de Valdivia, marking full-scale resistance.

result.general: Spanish partial victory but failure to fully subjugate the Mapuche; eventual annexation of Araucanía by Chile in 1883.
treaties: Treaty of Quilín (1641) – Spain recognized Mapuche autonomy south of the Bío-Bío River.
Pacification of Araucanía (1861–1883) – Chilean military annexed Mapuche lands.
result.territorial_changes: Araucanía remained largely independent until the late 19th century, when Chile annexed it.

allies: Various indigenous groups allied with Spain

Spain.troops: Varied over time; often 2,000 – 6,000 soldiers, including indigenous auxiliaries
Spain.fortifications: Several fortified towns such as Concepción, Valdivia, and Villarica
Spain.ships: Naval presence along the Pacific coast

Mapuche.tactics: Guerrilla warfare, ambushes, use of fortified villages
Mapuche.weapons: Spears, slings, wooden clubs, later acquired firearms and horses from the Spanish

Spain.dead: Thousands over the centuries, including several Spanish governors and soldiers
Spain.wounded: Unknown, but significant due to continuous warfare

Mapuche.dead: High casualties due to warfare, forced labor, and disease
Mapuche.displacement: Significant loss of land, but retained independence until late 19th century

major_battles.name: Battle of Tucapel
major_battles.description: Mapuche forces led by Lautaro ambushed and killed Spanish governor Pedro de Valdivia, dealing a major blow to Spanish ambitions in Araucanía.

major_battles.name: Battle of Curalaba
major_battles.description: Mapuche forces led by Pelantaro annihilated a Spanish column and initiated the destruction of Spanish cities south of the Bío-Bío River.
major_battles.outcome: Mapuche victory; Spanish abandoned several settlements.

major_battles.name: Pacification of Araucanía
major_battles.description: Chileans launched a full-scale military campaign to subdue the Mapuche and incorporate Araucanía into the Republic of Chile.

texts.name: La Araucana
texts.author: Alonso de Ercilla
texts.details: A Spanish epic poem written by a soldier who witnessed the Arauco War, providing one of the earliest European perspectives on Mapuche resistance.

texts.name: Spanish Colonial Reports
texts.details: Official reports from Spanish governors describing the ongoing conflict and Spanish attempts to control Araucanía.

archaeological_evidence.description: Ruins of Spanish forts, including Fort Nacimiento and Fort Purén, show defensive measures used in the conflict.
Spears, stone tools, and firearms adapted by the Mapuche found in excavation sites.

historical_texts.name: Diario de Guerra de Chile
historical_texts.author: Francisco Núñez de Pineda y Bascuñán
historical_texts.details: Firsthand Spanish account of captivity among the Mapuche, describing their society and resistance tactics.

political: Spain failed to fully conquer Araucanía, leading to the region's semi-independent status for centuries.
Chile eventually annexed Araucanía in 1883, incorporating it into the republic but facing ongoing indigenous tensions.
long_term_effects: Mapuche resistance shaped Chilean identity and influenced later indigenous movements.
The war left a legacy of conflict between the Chilean state and the Mapuche people, persisting into the modern era.

military: One of the longest indigenous resistance wars in world history.
Illustrated the effectiveness of guerrilla warfare against European armies.
political: Set the foundation for Chile's later territorial expansion and indigenous policies.
Highlighted the limits of Spanish colonial control in the Americas.
cultural: The war inspired Chilean literature, including the famous epic poem 'La Araucana'.
Mapuche identity remains strong in Chile today, with ongoing demands for land rights and autonomy.
